content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my moderately cautious nature and preference for security, I would opt for a strategy that maximizes the chance of earning a relatively consistent payoff throughout the game while minimizing the risk of losing significantly. In this case, if I choose R, I have a 50% chance of getting 45$ (when my partner chooses R) and a 50% chance of getting 0$ (if they choose B). On the other hand, if I choose B, I have a 100% chance of getting 12$, but I will miss out on the higher payout of 45$.

However, since the game has 75 rounds, it is likely that my partner will not consistently pick R for all 75 rounds. In fact, they are statistically expected to choose B more often than R because the 12$ payout from choosing B is still higher than the 0$ payout if I choose R and they choose B.

Given this analysis, it seems reasonable to expect that my partner will pick B more frequently than R over the course of 75 rounds. Therefore, by choosing R, I increase the likelihood of earning a higher overall payout compared to choosing B. To make a decision, I would choose:

R{}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, I took a risk by choosing R when my opponent chose B. Since I received 0$ in this round, I am now at a loss of 45$ - 0$ = 45$ compared to the scenario where I would have chosen B and earned 12$.

Moving forward, I will update my strategy based on the information gathered from the previous round. Since my opponent chose B in this round, I now know that they are more likely to choose B again in the future rounds, as their payoff is higher when I pick R and they pick B (42$ compared to 0$).

However, because the game has a large number of rounds (75), it is still reasonable to expect that my opponent will occasionally choose R. In this case, I can maximize my overall earnings by adjusting my strategy to be more flexible and adaptive to their choices. Instead of rigidly sticking to one choice, I can employ a mixed strategy in which I switch between R and B, depending on the pattern observed in my opponent's choices.

By adopting a mixed strategy, I increase the likelihood of earning positive payoffs when my opponent chooses R, while still being able to earn 12$ most of the time (when they choose B) without incurring significant losses. Therefore, for the next round, I will choose:

B{}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I chose B and my opponent also chose B. As a result, we both earn 12$ each in this round. Now that I have observed my opponent choosing B again, I can continue to employ a mixed strategy for future rounds to maximize my overall earnings.

Since my opponent has shown a pattern of choosing B consistently, I can take advantage of this information by occasionally switching to R when I expect them to choose B again (to maximize the chances of earning 45$), and vice versa (to minimize the risk of losing significantly). By adapting my strategy based on the observed patterns, I can aim for a higher overall payoff throughout the game.

Therefore, for the next round, I will choose:

Since my opponent has chosen R in this round, it suggests that they might be more likely to switch to B in the future rounds, as their payoff would be higher when I pick R and they choose B (42$ compared to 0$). In such a case, I can maximize my overall earnings by occasionally switching to B, while still maintaining some frequency of choosing R to take advantage of situations where my opponent chooses R again.
